title: My visit to the Somme emphasised the importance of working together to achieve the best for all
text:
My visit to the Somme emphasised the importance of working together to achieve the best for all 18:30, 8 Jul 2016 Writing for ChronicleLive, Chi Onwurah, Labour MP for Newcastle Central, reflects on the anniversary of the Somme on week on Shares Get daily news by email Chi Onwurah at the Somme memorial 
Last week I left Parliament to visit the Somme. I am sure most people will understand if I say that after Brexit, the vote of (no) confidence in Jeremy Corbyn and the start of the Tory leadership campaign, I was quite desperate for the peace, tranquillity and reflection of such an important and historic battlefield. 
Some accused me of running away! In reality The Northumberland Fusiliers Battlefields Tour was organised over a year ago to commemorate the one hundredth anniversary of the first day of the Somme when thousands of Tynesiders died. 
As a member of the Franco-British Council I helped identify the right French contacts for the civil and military permissions required. Though I knew it was the weekend after the EU referendum I didn’t think it would be the weekend after Brexit. 
So that is why the first time I used my European Union passport after Britain voted to leave the EU was to join 150 veterans, cadets, reservists and their families and supporters en route to the village of La Boisselle in the Somme, via the great battlefields around Ypres in Belgium. We spent four days remembering and paying our respects to those who had died, visiting a number of Commonwealth War Cemeteries as well as German, Belgian, Italian and Canadian memorials and holding our own ceremony of remembrance at La Boisselle, just five kilometres from the official Franco-British ceremony at Thiepval attended by the Prime Minster, Jeremy Corbyn, Prince William and the British and French Ambassadors. 
I had long wanted to visit the battlefields. I have always loved the Response memorial in the Civic Centre and as a child the knowledge that my father was in the Armed Services in the Biafran War made the sight of families waving men off to war very personal. 
And it was an incredibly moving visit. At La Boisselle on July 1 1916 4,000 men of the Northumberland Fusiliers Tyneside Irish and Tyneside Scottish Battalions died, most before midday, in an attempt to destroy enemy artillery. 
Their sacrifice is commemorated by La Boisselle Tyneside Memorial Seat and at 7.28 on the Friday, 100 years to the minute from when the order to ‘go over the top’ was given, we assembled there to pay our respects. 
Local people watched in silence as representatives of the Fusiliers, Cadets, Green Howards and civil society, including myself and Ian Mearns, lay wreathes to the sound of Scottish and Northumberland pipes, hymns and a hearty rendition of the Blaydon Races. 
Historian John Sheen read a moving tribute to the men that died that day. Actually being there for the anniversary bought to life some of the realities of that morning 100 years ago, the lack of cover, the importance of height, the humour of the soldiers –the two shallow valleys South and North of a low rise were called Sausage and Mash respectively. The nearby Tyne Cot cemetery was named by Northumbrian Fusiliers for a disused German barn originally on the site which reminded them of a Tyneside Cottage. 
It is now the largest Commonwealth War Grave where 11,953 are buried and 34,870 names of unidentified soldiers. Reading just some of those names underlined the horror of war that we fortunately have not had to experience and all the humour in the world cannot efface. 
We also visited a much smaller commonwealth cemetery in Ypres, but one with strong ties to Newcastle. It is here that the two sons of Sir James Knott were buried. The memorial fund Sir James set up built St James and St Basils in Fenham as well as Knott Hall in Heddon-on- the-Wall. Both Commonwealth War cemeteries were on land gratefully gifted by the Belgians in perpetuity. 
Finally, Fusiliers laid wreathes at the Menin Gate, watched with such respect and appreciation by tourists and local residents alike it brought tears to the eye. 
Of course it was not possible to totally escape Brexit. Some Belgians raised it with us, one of our party was abused in a bar by a local woman when he said he had voted to leave the European Union, as many on the tour appeared to have done. 
I was told the vote had caused divisions within families and the point was made to me that Labour had to show that it understood why so many of our supporters voted as they did. 
I campaigned strongly for Remain, and I believed it was in the best interest of Newcastle, the North East and the country. 
But my visit to the Somme emphasised to me just how important it is that we all work together to achieve what is best for the North East and the country and Europe, and that inside or outside of the EU, our shared history and sacrifice merits a relationship that is both mutually supportive and constructive. 
• Chi would like to thank Fusiliers Battlefield Tour Organisers and Participants. Battle of the Somme at 100 years
